head.title: Giving Buffett the Boots In a Corporate Farewell

hedline.hl1: Giving Buffett the Boots In a Corporate Farewell

abstract.p: John Justin intends to close $600 million sale of his Justin Industries bricks-and-boots business to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway with a pair of ostrich-skin cowboy boots; Justin makes Justin, Tony Lamas and Noconas boot brands; photo (M)

block.p: Some deals are sealed with a handshake, others with a toast.
But John Justin, the 83-year-old patriarch of Justin Industries, is closing the sale of his company to Warren E. Buffett with a pair of ostrich-skin cowboy boots.
Some deals are sealed with a handshake, others with a toast.
But John Justin, the 83-year-old patriarch of Justin Industries, is closing the sale of his company to Warren E. Buffett with a pair of ostrich-skin cowboy boots.

''I imagine something sort of like what I got on,'' said Mr. Justin from his headquarters in Fort Worth. ''A kind of souped-up roper boot.'' Besides Justin boots, the company makes Tony Lamas and Noconas.

Mr. Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway announced its plan to buy Mr. Justin's brick-and-boot company on Tuesday for $600 million, has plenty of footwear to choose from, since his company already owns the shoemakers H. H. Brown and Dexter.

But Berkshire probably bought Justin for its bricks, not its boots. Bricks, riding the Southwest's housing boom, account for two-thirds of Justin's revenue and nearly all its profits. Mr. Buffett is even said to have a fondness for the material, solid and dependable like his preferred brands.
''He indicated that his house is built of bricks and he has owned it for many years,'' said John Roach, the chairman of Justin Industries.

But sending Mr. Buffett a block of baked clay hardly seemed a fitting end to family ownership that had been unbroken since 1879. Not a common gift item either, Mr. Justin said, adding, ''Be a tough deal to wrap.''
